children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: ploidy
children.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2018-03-27) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: number of replicons
children.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

children.name: extrachromosomal elements
children.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

children.name: estimated size
children.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

children.name: reference for biomaterial
children.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

children.name: annotation source
children.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

children.name: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
children.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term 'sample size'.

children.name: nucleic acid extraction
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

children.name: nucleic acid amplification
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library construction method
children.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: target gene
children.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

children.name: target subfragment
children.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

children.name: pcr primers
children.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: pcr conditions
children.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

children.name: sequencing method
children.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).

children.name: sequence quality check
children.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

children.name: chimera check software
children.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: negative control type
children.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

children.name: positive control type
children.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive.

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: altitude
children.description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: elevation
children.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

children.name: ventilation rate
children.description: ventilation rate of the system in the sampled premises

children.name: ventilation type
children.description: The intentional movement of air from outside a building to the inside through forced or natural movement of air

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: isolation and growth condition
children.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

children.name: propagation
children.description: The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa. For phage or virus: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic. For plasmids: incompatibility group. For eukaryotes: sexual/asexual. Mandatory for MIGs of eukayotes, plasmids and viruses.

children.name: amount or size of sample collected
children.description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected.

children.name: oxygenation status of sample
children.description: oxygenation status of sample

children.name: organism count
children.description: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample, should include name of organism followed by count. The method that was used for the enumeration (e.g. qPCR, atp, mpn, etc.) Should also be provided. (example: total prokaryotes; 3.5e7 cells per ml; qpcr)

children.name: sample storage duration
children.description: duration for which sample was stored

children.name: sample storage temperature
children.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

children.name: sample storage location
children.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

children.name: sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: host disease status
children.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

children.name: host scientific name
children.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

children.name: barometric pressure
children.description: force per unit area exerted against a surface by the weight of air above that surface

children.name: humidity
children.description: amount of water vapour in the air, at the time of sampling

children.name: pollutants
children.description: pollutant types and, amount or concentrations measured at the time of sampling; can report multiple pollutants by entering numeric values preceded by name of pollutant

children.name: solar irradiance
children.description: the amount of solar energy that arrives at a specific area of a surface during a specific time interval

children.name: wind direction
children.description: wind direction is the direction from which a wind originates

children.name: wind speed
children.description: speed of wind measured at the time of sampling

children.name: temperature
children.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

children.name: carbon dioxide
children.description: carbon dioxide (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

children.name: carbon monoxide
children.description: carbon monoxide (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

children.name: oxygen
children.description: oxygen (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

children.name: air particulate matter concentration
children.description: Concentration of substances that remain suspended in the air, and comprise mixtures of organic and inorganic substances (PM10 and PM2.5); can report multiple PM's by entering numeric values preceded by name of PM

children.name: volatile organic compounds
children.description: concentration of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature; can report multiple volatile organic compounds by entering numeric values preceded by name of compound

children.name: methane
children.description: methane (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

children.name: salinity
children.description: The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

children.name: subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: trophic level
children.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: known pathogenicity
children.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

children.name: encoded traits
children.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

children.name: observed biotic relationship
children.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

children.name: chemical administration
children.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

children.name: perturbation
children.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: sample collection: methods, storage and transport
sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: metagenomic source
children.description: The metagenomic source of the sample. This value should contain “metagenome” and be in the taxonomy database e.g. wastewater metagenome or human gut metagenome. Please note “metagenome” alone will not be accepted. Check here for more details on metagenome taxonomy: https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq_taxonomy.html#environmental-taxonomic-classifications

children.name: sample derived from
children.description: Reference to parental sample(s) or original run(s) that the assembly is derived from. The referenced samples or runs should already be registered in INSDC. This should be formatted as one of the following. A single sample/run e.g. ERSxxxxxx OR a comma separated list e.g. ERSxxxxxx,ERSxxxxxx OR a range e.g. ERSxxxxxx-ERSxxxxxx

children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: number of standard tRNAs extracted
children.description: The total number of tRNAs identified from the bin, SAG or MAG

children.name: feature prediction
children.description: Method used to predict UViGs features such as ORFs, integration site, etc. Add names and versions of software(s), parameters used

children.name: similarity search method
children.description: Tool used to compare ORFs with database, along with version and cutoffs used. Add names and versions of software(s), parameters used

children.name: 16s recovered
children.description: Can a 16S gene be recovered from the submitted bin, SAG or MAG?

children.name: 16S recovery software
children.description: Tools used for 16S rRNA gene extraction. Add names and versions of software(s), parameters used

children.name: tRNA extraction software
children.description: Tools used for tRNA identification. Add names and versions of software(s), parameters used

children.name: completeness score
children.description: Completeness score is typically based on either the fraction of markers found as compared to a database or the percent of a genome found as compared to a closely related reference genome. Completeness score is one of 3 attributes which in combination reflect the standard quality of a MAG, see here for more information: https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq_metagenomes.html. Mandatory for all samples directly linked with SAGs or MAGs.

children.name: completeness software
children.description: Tools used for completion estimate, i.e. checkm, anvi'o, busco. Mandatory for all samples directly linked with SAGs or MAGs.

children.name: completeness approach
children.description: The approach used to determine the completeness of a given bin, SAG or MAG, which would typically make use of a set of conserved marker genes or a closely related reference genome. For UViG completeness, include reference genome or group used, and contig feature suggesting a complete genome

children.name: contamination score
children.description: The contamination score is based on the fraction of single-copy genes that are observed more than once in a query genome. Contamination score is one of 3 attributes which in combination reflect the standard quality of a MAG, see here for more information: https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq_metagenomes.html. If contamination ≥ 10% then please submit as a binned assembly. In SAGs, contamination score is mandatory for prokaryotes and optional for eukaryotes.

children.name: contamination screening input
children.description: The type of sequence data used as input

children.name: contamination screening parameters
children.description: Specific parameters used in the decontamination sofware, such as reference database, coverage, and kmers. Combinations of these parameters may also be used, i.e. kmer and coverage, or reference database and kmer

children.name: decontamination software
children.description: Tool(s) used in contamination screening

children.name: binning software
children.description: Tool(s) used for the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets, where possible include a product ID (PID) of the tool(s) used. E.g. MetaCluster-TA (RRID:SCR_004599) or MaxBin (biotools:maxbin)

children.name: reassembly post binning
children.description: Has an assembly been performed on a genome bin extracted from a metagenomic assembly?

children.name: MAG coverage software
children.description: Tool(s) used to determine the genome coverage if coverage is used as a binning parameter in the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets e.g. bwa, bbmap, bowtie, other

children.name: assembly quality
children.description: The assembly quality category is based on sets of criteria outlined for each assembly quality category. For MISAG/MIMAG; Finished: Single, validated, contiguous sequence per replicon without gaps or ambiguities with a consensus error rate equivalent to Q50 or better. High Quality Draft:Multiple fragments where gaps span repetitive regions. Presence of the 23S, 16S and 5S rRNA genes and at least 18 tRNAs. Medium Quality Draft:Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics. Low Quality Draft:Many fragments with little to no review of assembly other than reporting of standard assembly statistics. Assembly statistics include, but are not limited to total assembly size, number of contigs, contig N50/L50, and maximum contig length. For MIUVIG; Finished: Single, validated, contiguous sequence per replicon without gaps or ambiguities, with extensive manual review and editing to annotate putative gene functions and transcriptional units. High-quality draft genome: One or multiple fragments, totaling ≥ 90% of the expected genome or replicon sequence or predicted complete. Genome fragment(s): One or multiple fragments, totalling < 90% of the expected genome or replicon sequence, or for which no genome size could be estimated.

children.name: binning parameters
children.description: The parameters that have been applied during the extraction of genomes from metagenomic datasets e.g. coverage and kmer

children.name: taxonomic identity marker
children.description: The phylogenetic marker(s) used to assign an organism name to the bin, SAG or MAG. Examples are 16S gene, multi-marker approach or other e.g. rpoB gene. Mandatory for all samples directly linked with SAGs or MAGs.

children.name: isolation_source
children.description: describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: altitude
children.description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: elevation
children.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

children.name: amount or size of sample collected
children.description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected.

children.name: size fraction selected
children.description: Filtering pore size used in sample preparation e.g. 0-0.22 micrometer

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The geographical origin of where the sample was collected from, with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: taxonomic classification
children.description: Method used for taxonomic classification, along with reference database used, classification rank, and thresholds used to classify new genomes. Expected values are: classification method, database name, and other parameters e.g. vConTACT vContact2 (references from NCBI RefSeq v83, genus rank classification, default parameters)

children.name: annotation source
children.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

children.name: reference for biomaterial
children.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

children.name: reference database(s)
children.description: List of database(s) used for ORF annotation, along with version number and reference to website or publication

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: nucleic acid extraction
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

children.name: nucleic acid amplification
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: assembly software
children.description: Tool(s) used for assembly, including version number and parameters in the format {software};{version};{parameters} e.g. metaSPAdes;3.11.0;kmer set 21,33,55,77,99,121, default parameters otherwise

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: depth
children.description: The vertical distance below local surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: ploidy
children.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2018-03-27) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: number of replicons
children.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

children.name: extrachromosomal elements
children.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

children.name: estimated size
children.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

children.name: reference for biomaterial
children.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

children.name: annotation source
children.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

children.name: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
children.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term 'sample size'.

children.name: nucleic acid extraction
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

children.name: nucleic acid amplification
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library construction method
children.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: target gene
children.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

children.name: target subfragment
children.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

children.name: pcr primers
children.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: pcr conditions
children.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

children.name: sequencing method
children.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).

children.name: sequence quality check
children.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

children.name: chimera check software
children.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: negative control type
children.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

children.name: positive control type
children.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive.

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: altitude
children.description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: depth
children.description: The vertical distance below local surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: elevation
children.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: isolation and growth condition
children.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

children.name: propagation
children.description: The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa. For phage or virus: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic. For plasmids: incompatibility group. For eukaryotes: sexual/asexual. Mandatory for MIGs of eukayotes, plasmids and viruses.

children.name: amount or size of sample collected
children.description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected.

children.name: host dry mass
children.description: measurement of dry mass

children.name: oxygenation status of sample
children.description: oxygenation status of sample

children.name: plant product
children.description: substance produced by the plant, where the sample was obtained from

children.name: organism count
children.description: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample, should include name of organism followed by count. The method that was used for the enumeration (e.g. qPCR, atp, mpn, etc.) Should also be provided. (example: total prokaryotes; 3.5e7 cells per ml; qpcr)

children.name: sample storage duration
children.description: duration for which sample was stored

children.name: sample storage temperature
children.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

children.name: host wet mass
children.description: measurement of wet mass

children.name: sample storage location
children.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

children.name: sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: host disease status
children.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

children.name: host common name
children.description: common name of the host, e.g. human

children.name: host age
children.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

children.name: host taxid
children.description: NCBI taxon id of the host, e.g. 9606

children.name: host life stage
children.description: description of life stage of host

children.name: host height
children.description: the height of subject

children.name: host length
children.description: the length of subject

children.name: plant body site
children.description: name of body site that the sample was obtained from. For Plant Ontology (PO) (v 20) terms, see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PO

children.name: host total mass
children.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

children.name: host phenotype
children.description: phenotype of host. For Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: host subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the host organism below the subspecies level e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, variety, cultivar, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: climate environment
children.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular climate; can include multiple climates

children.name: gaseous environment
children.description: use of conditions with differing gaseous environments; should include the name of gaseous compound, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple gaseous environment regimens

children.name: seasonal environment
children.description: treatment involving an exposure to a particular season (e.g. winter, summer, rabi, rainy etc.)

children.name: temperature
children.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

children.name: salinity
children.description: The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

children.name: host genotype
children.description: observed genotype

children.name: subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: trophic level
children.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: known pathogenicity
children.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

children.name: encoded traits
children.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

children.name: observed biotic relationship
children.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

children.name: air temperature regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying temperatures; should include the temperature, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include different temperature regimens

children.name: antibiotic regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving antibiotic administration; should include the name of antibiotic, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple antibiotic regimens

children.name: chemical mutagen
children.description: treatment involving use of mutagens; should include the name of mutagen, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mutagen regimens

children.name: fertilizer regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving the use of fertilizers; should include the name fertilizer, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fertilizer regimens

children.name: fungicide regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving use of fungicides; should include the name of fungicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple fungicide regimens

children.name: gravity
children.description: information about treatment involving use of gravity factor to study various types of responses in presence, absence or modified levels of gravity; can include multiple treatments

children.name: growth hormone regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of growth hormone, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple growth hormone regimens

children.name: growth media
children.description: information about growth media for growing the plants or tissue cultured samples

children.name: herbicide regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving use of herbicides; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include the name of herbicide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

children.name: humidity regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to varying degree of humidity; information about treatment involving use of growth hormones; should include amount of humidity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple regimens

children.name: mineral nutrient regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving the use of mineral supplements; should include the name of mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple mineral nutrient regimens

children.name: non-mineral nutrient regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving the exposure of plant to non-mineral nutrient such as oxygen, hydrogen or carbon; should include the name of non-mineral nutrient, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple non-mineral nutrient regimens

children.name: pesticide regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving use of insecticides; should include the name of pesticide, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple pesticide regimens

children.name: pH regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plants to varying levels of pH of the growth media; can include multiple regimen

children.name: radiation regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving exposure of plant or a plant part to a particular radiation regimen; should include the radiation type, amount or intensity administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple radiation regimens

children.name: rainfall regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to a given amount of rainfall; can include multiple regimens

children.name: salt regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving use of salts as supplement to liquid and soil growth media; should include the name of salt, amount administered, treatment duration, interval and total experimental duration; can include multiple salt regimens

children.name: standing water regimen
children.description: treatment involving an exposure to standing water during a plant's life span, types can be flood water or standing water; can include multiple regimens

children.name: tissue culture growth media
children.description: description of plant tissue culture growth media used

children.name: watering regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to watering frequencies; can include multiple regimens

children.name: water temperature regimen
children.description: information about treatment involving an exposure to water with varying degree of temperature; can include multiple regimens

children.name: mechanical damage
children.description: information about any mechanical damage exerted on the plant; can include multiple damages and sites

children.name: chemical administration
children.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

children.name: perturbation
children.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: sample storage duration
children.description: duration for which sample was stored

children.name: sample storage temperature
children.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

children.name: sample storage location
children.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

children.name: sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: biochemical oxygen demand
children.description: a measure of the relative oxygen-depletion effect of a waste contaminant

children.name: chemical oxygen demand
children.description: a measure of the relative oxygen-depletion effect of a waste contaminant

children.name: pre-treatment
children.description: the process of pre-treatment removes materials that can be easily collected from the raw wastewater

children.name: primary treatment
children.description: the process to produce both a generally homogeneous liquid capable of being treated biologically and a sludge that can be separately treated or processed

children.name: reactor type
children.description: anaerobic digesters can be designed and engineered to operate using a number of different process configurations, as batch or continuous, mesophilic, high solid or low solid, and single stage or multistage

children.name: secondary treatment
children.description: the process for substantially degrading the biological content of the sewage

children.name: sludge retention time
children.description: the time activated sludge remains in reactor

children.name: tertiary treatment
children.description: the process providing a final treatment stage to raise the effluent quality before it is discharged to the receiving environment

children.name: host disease status
children.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

children.name: host scientific name
children.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

children.name: alkalinity
children.description: alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate

children.name: industrial effluent percent
children.description: percentage of industrial effluents received by wastewater treatment plant

children.name: sewage type
children.description: Type of sewage based on origin: wastewater treatment plant (municipal or industrial), open sewer line, river, stream, stagnant pool, or other.

children.name: wastewater type
children.description: the origin of wastewater such as human waste, rainfall, storm drains, etc.

children.name: temperature
children.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

children.name: pH
children.description: pH measurement

children.name: efficiency percent
children.description: percentage of volatile solids removed from the anaerobic digestor

children.name: emulsions
children.description: amount or concentration of substances such as paints, adhesives, mayonnaise, hair colorants, emulsified oils, etc.; can include multiple emulsion types

children.name: gaseous substances
children.description: amount or concentration of substances such as hydrogen sulfide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.; can include multiple substances

children.name: inorganic particles
children.description: concentration of particles such as sand, grit, metal particles, ceramics, etc.; can include multiple particles

children.name: organic particles
children.description: concentration of particles such as faeces, hairs, food, vomit, paper fibers, plant material, humus, etc.

children.name: soluble inorganic material
children.description: concentration of substances such as ammonia, road-salt, sea-salt, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, thiocyanates, thiosulfates, etc.

children.name: soluble organic material
children.description: concentration of substances such as urea, fruit sugars, soluble proteins, drugs, pharmaceuticals, etc.

children.name: suspended solids
children.description: concentration of substances including a wide variety of material, such as silt, decaying plant and animal matter, etc,; can include multiple substances

children.name: total phosphate
children.description: total amount or concentration of phosphate

children.name: nitrate
children.description: concentration of nitrate

children.name: phosphate
children.description: concentration of phosphate

children.name: salinity
children.description: The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

children.name: sodium
children.description: sodium concentration

children.name: total nitrogen
children.description: total nitrogen content of the sample

children.name: subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: trophic level
children.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: known pathogenicity
children.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

children.name: encoded traits
children.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

children.name: observed biotic relationship
children.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

children.name: chemical administration
children.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

children.name: perturbation
children.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

name: GSC MIxS miscellaneous natural or artificial environment

children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: ploidy
children.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2018-03-27) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: number of replicons
children.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

children.name: extrachromosomal elements
children.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

children.name: estimated size
children.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

children.name: reference for biomaterial
children.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

children.name: annotation source
children.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

children.name: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
children.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term 'sample size'.

children.name: nucleic acid extraction
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

children.name: nucleic acid amplification
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library construction method
children.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: target gene
children.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

children.name: target subfragment
children.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

children.name: pcr primers
children.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: pcr conditions
children.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

children.name: sequencing method
children.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).

children.name: sequence quality check
children.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

children.name: chimera check software
children.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: negative control type
children.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

children.name: positive control type
children.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive.

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: altitude
children.description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: depth
children.description: The vertical distance below local surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: elevation
children.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: isolation and growth condition
children.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

children.name: propagation
children.description: The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa. For phage or virus: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic. For plasmids: incompatibility group. For eukaryotes: sexual/asexual. Mandatory for MIGs of eukayotes, plasmids and viruses.
