children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library construction method
children.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: target gene
children.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

children.name: target subfragment
children.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

children.name: pcr primers
children.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: pcr conditions
children.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

children.name: sequencing method
children.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).

children.name: sequence quality check
children.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

children.name: chimera check software
children.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: negative control type
children.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

children.name: positive control type
children.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive.

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: altitude
children.description: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: depth
children.description: The vertical distance below local surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: elevation
children.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: isolation and growth condition
children.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

children.name: propagation
children.description: The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa. For phage or virus: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic. For plasmids: incompatibility group. For eukaryotes: sexual/asexual. Mandatory for MIGs of eukayotes, plasmids and viruses.

children.name: amount or size of sample collected
children.description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected.

children.name: biomass
children.description: amount of biomass; should include the name for the part of biomass measured, e.g. microbial, total. can include multiple measurements

children.name: oxygenation status of sample
children.description: oxygenation status of sample

children.name: organism count
children.description: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample, should include name of organism followed by count. The method that was used for the enumeration (e.g. qPCR, atp, mpn, etc.) Should also be provided. (example: total prokaryotes; 3.5e7 cells per ml; qpcr)

children.name: sample storage duration
children.description: duration for which sample was stored

children.name: sample storage temperature
children.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

children.name: sample storage location
children.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

children.name: sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: host disease status
children.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

children.name: host scientific name
children.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

children.name: alkalinity
children.description: alkalinity, the ability of a solution to neutralize acids to the equivalence point of carbonate or bicarbonate

children.name: mean friction velocity
children.description: measurement of mean friction velocity

children.name: mean peak friction velocity
children.description: measurement of mean peak friction velocity

children.name: pressure
children.description: pressure to which the sample is subject, in atmospheres

children.name: temperature
children.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

children.name: turbidity
children.description: turbidity measurement

children.name: pH
children.description: pH measurement

children.name: alkyl diethers
children.description: concentration of alkyl diethers

children.name: aminopeptidase activity
children.description: measurement of aminopeptidase activity

children.name: ammonium
children.description: concentration of ammonium

children.name: bacterial carbon production
children.description: measurement of bacterial carbon production

children.name: bishomohopanol
children.description: concentration of bishomohopanol

children.name: bromide
children.description: concentration of bromide

children.name: calcium
children.description: concentration of calcium

children.name: carbon/nitrogen ratio
children.description: ratio of amount or concentrations of carbon to nitrogen

children.name: chloride
children.description: concentration of chloride

children.name: chlorophyll
children.description: concentration of chlorophyll

children.name: diether lipids
children.description: concentration of diether lipids; can include multiple types of diether lipids

children.name: dissolved carbon dioxide
children.description: concentration of dissolved carbon dioxide

children.name: dissolved hydrogen
children.description: concentration of dissolved hydrogen

children.name: dissolved inorganic carbon
children.description: dissolved inorganic carbon concentration

children.name: dissolved organic carbon
children.description: concentration of dissolved organic carbon

children.name: dissolved organic nitrogen
children.description: dissolved organic nitrogen concentration measured as; total dissolved nitrogen - NH4 - NO3 - NO2

children.name: methane
children.description: methane (gas) amount or concentration at the time of sampling

children.name: dissolved oxygen
children.description: concentration of dissolved oxygen

children.name: glucosidase activity
children.description: measurement of glucosidase activity

children.name: magnesium
children.description: concentration of magnesium

children.name: n-alkanes
children.description: concentration of n-alkanes; can include multiple n-alkanes

children.name: nitrate
children.description: concentration of nitrate

children.name: nitrite
children.description: concentration of nitrite

children.name: nitrogen
children.description: concentration of nitrogen (total)

children.name: organic carbon
children.description: concentration of organic carbon

children.name: organic matter
children.description: concentration of organic matter

children.name: organic nitrogen
children.description: concentration of organic nitrogen

children.name: particulate organic carbon
children.description: concentration of particulate organic carbon

children.name: petroleum hydrocarbon
children.description: concentration of petroleum hydrocarbon

children.name: phaeopigments
children.description: concentration of phaeopigments; can include multiple phaeopigments

children.name: phosphate
children.description: concentration of phosphate

children.name: phospholipid fatty acid
children.description: concentration of phospholipid fatty acids; can include multiple values

children.name: potassium
children.description: concentration of potassium

children.name: redox potential
children.description: redox potential, measured relative to a hydrogen cell, indicating oxidation or reduction potential

children.name: salinity
children.description: The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

children.name: total carbon
children.description: total carbon content

children.name: silicate
children.description: concentration of silicate

children.name: sodium
children.description: sodium concentration

children.name: total organic carbon
children.description: Definition for soil: total organic C content of the soil units of g C/kg soil. Definition otherwise: total organic carbon content

children.name: water content
children.description: water content measurement

children.name: sulfate
children.description: concentration of sulfate

children.name: sulfide
children.description: concentration of sulfide

children.name: total nitrogen
children.description: total nitrogen content of the sample

children.name: subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: trophic level
children.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: known pathogenicity
children.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

children.name: encoded traits
children.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

children.name: observed biotic relationship
children.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

children.name: chemical administration
children.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

children.name: perturbation
children.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

children.name: project name
children.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

children.name: experimental factor
children.description: Experimental factors are essentially the variable aspects of an experiment design which can be used to describe an experiment, or set of experiments, in an increasingly detailed manner. This field accepts ontology terms from Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO) and/or Ontology for Biomedical Investigations (OBI). For a browser of EFO (v 2.95) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/EFO; for a browser of OBI (v 2018-02-12) terms please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/OBI. E.g. time series design [EFO:EFO_0001779]

children.name: ploidy
children.description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2018-03-27) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: number of replicons
children.description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea and segmented virus.

children.name: extrachromosomal elements
children.description: Do plasmids exist of significant phenotypic consequence (e.g. ones that determine virulence or antibiotic resistance). Megaplasmids? Other plasmids (borrelia has 15+ plasmids).

children.name: estimated size
children.description: The estimated size of the genome (in bp) prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period. Mandatory for MIGS of eukaryotes.

children.name: reference for biomaterial
children.description: Primary publication if isolated before genome publication; otherwise, primary genome report. Mandatory for MIGS of bacteria and archaea.

children.name: annotation source
children.description: For cases where annotation was provided by a community jamboree or model organism database rather than by a specific submitter

children.name: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
children.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term 'sample size'.

children.name: nucleic acid extraction
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

children.name: nucleic acid amplification
children.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the enzymatic amplification (PCR, TMA, NASBA) of specific nucleic acids

children.name: library size
children.description: Total number of clones in the library prepared for the project

children.name: library reads sequenced
children.description: Total number of clones sequenced from the library

children.name: library construction method
children.description: Library construction method used for clone libraries

children.name: library vector
children.description: Cloning vector type(s) used in construction of libraries

children.name: library screening strategy
children.description: Specific enrichment or screening methods applied before and/or after creating clone libraries in order to select a specific group of sequences

children.name: target gene
children.description: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies

children.name: target subfragment
children.description: Name of subfragment of a gene or locus. Important to e.g. identify special regions on marker genes like V6 on 16S rRNA

children.name: pcr primers
children.description: PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment. This field should contain all the primers used for a single PCR reaction if multiple forward or reverse primers are present in a single PCR reaction. The primer sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: multiplex identifiers
children.description: Molecular barcodes, called Multiplex Identifiers (MIDs), that are used to specifically tag unique samples in a sequencing run. Sequence should be reported in uppercase letters

children.name: adapters
children.description: Adapters provide priming sequences for both amplification and sequencing of the sample-library fragments. Both adapters should be reported; in uppercase letters

children.name: pcr conditions
children.description: Description of reaction conditions and components for PCR in the form of 'initial denaturation:94degC_1.5min; annealing=...'

children.name: sequencing method
children.description: Sequencing machine used. Where possible the term should be taken from the OBI list of DNA sequencers (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0400103).

children.name: sequence quality check
children.description: Indicate if the sequence has been called by automatic systems (none) or undergone a manual editing procedure (e.g. by inspecting the raw data or chromatograms). Applied only for sequences that are not submitted to SRA or DRA

children.name: chimera check software
children.description: Tool(s) used for chimera checking, including version number and parameters, to discover and remove chimeric sequences. A chimeric sequence is comprised of two or more phylogenetically distinct parent sequences.

children.name: relevant electronic resources
children.description: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise associated to the sequence in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: relevant standard operating procedures
children.description: Standard operating procedures used in assembly and/or annotation of genomes, metagenomes or environmental sequences in the format of a PMID, DOI or URL

children.name: negative control type
children.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

children.name: positive control type
children.description: The substance, mixture, product, or apparatus used to verify that a process which is part of an investigation delivers a true positive.

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (latitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (longitude)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: broad-scale environmental context
children.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: local environmental context
children.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

children.name: environmental medium
children.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

children.name: source material identifiers
children.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

children.name: sample material processing
children.description: A brief description of any processing applied to the sample during or after retrieving the sample from environment, or a link to the relevant protocol(s) performed.

children.name: isolation and growth condition
children.description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material. Mandatory for MIGS and MIMARKS Specimen.

children.name: propagation
children.description: The type of reproduction from the parent stock. Values for this field is specific to different taxa. For phage or virus: lytic/lysogenic/temperate/obligately lytic. For plasmids: incompatibility group. For eukaryotes: sexual/asexual. Mandatory for MIGs of eukayotes, plasmids and viruses.

children.name: amount or size of sample collected
children.description: The total amount or size (volume (ml), mass (g) or area (m2) ) of sample collected.

children.name: host body product
children.description: substance produced by the body, e.g. stool, mucus, where the sample was obtained from. For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

children.name: medical history performed
children.description: whether full medical history was collected

children.name: oxygenation status of sample
children.description: oxygenation status of sample

children.name: organism count
children.description: Total cell count of any organism (or group of organisms) per gram, volume or area of sample, should include name of organism followed by count. The method that was used for the enumeration (e.g. qPCR, atp, mpn, etc.) Should also be provided. (example: total prokaryotes; 3.5e7 cells per ml; qpcr)

children.name: sample storage duration
children.description: duration for which sample was stored

children.name: sample storage temperature
children.description: temperature at which sample was stored, e.g. -80

children.name: sample storage location
children.description: location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room

children.name: sample collection device
children.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

children.name: sample collection method
children.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

children.name: gynecological disorder
children.description: History of gynecological disorders; can include multiple disorders. The terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, female reproductive system disease (https://disease-ontology.org/?id=DOID:229).

children.name: urogenital disorder
children.description: History of urogenital disorders, can include multiple disorders. The terms should be chosen from the DO (Human Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, reproductive system disease (https://disease-ontology.org/?id=DOID:15) or urinary system disease (https://disease-ontology.org/?id=DOID:18).

children.name: host disease status
children.description: list of diseases with which the host has been diagnosed; can include multiple diagnoses. The value of the field depends on host; for humans the terms should be chosen from DO (Disease Ontology) at http://www.disease-ontology.org, other hosts are free text

children.name: host subject id
children.description: a unique identifier by which each subject can be referred to, de-identified, e.g. #131

children.name: IHMC medication code
children.description: can include multiple medication codes

children.name: host age
children.description: age of host at the time of sampling; relevant scale depends on species and study, e.g. could be seconds for amoebae or centuries for trees

children.name: host body site
children.description: name of body site where the sample was obtained from, such as a specific organ or tissue (tongue, lung etc...). For Foundational Model of Anatomy Ontology (FMA) (v 3.1) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/FMA

children.name: host height
children.description: the height of subject

children.name: host body-mass index
children.description: body mass index, calculated as weight/(height)squared

children.name: ethnicity
children.description: A category of people who identify with each other, usually on the basis of presumed similarities such as a common language, ancestry, history, society, culture, nation or social treatment within their residing area. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_contemporary_ethnic_groups

children.name: host occupation
children.description: most frequent job performed by subject

children.name: host total mass
children.description: total mass of the host at collection, the unit depends on host

children.name: host phenotype
children.description: phenotype of host. For Phenotypic quality Ontology (PATO) (v 2013-10-28) terms, please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

children.name: host body temperature
children.description: core body temperature of the host when sample was collected

children.name: host sex
children.description: Gender or sex of the host.

children.name: temperature
children.description: temperature of the sample at time of sampling

children.name: salinity
children.description: The total concentration of all dissolved salts in a liquid or solid sample. While salinity can be measured by a complete chemical analysis, this method is difficult and time consuming. More often, it is instead derived from the conductivity measurement. This is known as practical salinity. These derivations compare the specific conductance of the sample to a salinity standard such as seawater.

children.name: menarche
children.description: date of most recent menstruation

children.name: sexual activity
children.description: current sexual partner and frequency of sex

children.name: pregnancy
children.description: date due of pregnancy

children.name: douche
children.description: date of most recent douche

children.name: birth control
children.description: specification of birth control medication used

children.name: menopause
children.description: date of onset of menopause

children.name: HRT
children.description: whether subject had hormone replacement theraphy, and if yes start date

children.name: hysterectomy
children.description: specification of whether hysterectomy was performed

children.name: host diet
children.description: type of diet depending on the host, for animals omnivore, herbivore etc., for humans high-fat, Mediterranean etc.; can include multiple diet types

children.name: host last meal
children.description: content of last meal and time since feeding; can include multiple values

children.name: host family relationship
children.description: relationships to other hosts in the same study; can include multiple relationships

children.name: host genotype
children.description: observed genotype

children.name: host pulse
children.description: resting pulse, measured as beats per minute

children.name: subspecific genetic lineage
children.description: Information about the genetic distinctness of the sequenced organism below the subspecies level, e.g., serovar, serotype, biotype, ecotype, or any relevant genetic typing schemes like Group I plasmid. Subspecies should not be recorded in this term, but in the NCBI taxonomy. Supply both the lineage name and the lineage rank separated by a colon, e.g., biovar:abc123.

children.name: trophic level
children.description: Trophic levels are the feeding position in a food chain. Microbes can be a range of producers (e.g. chemolithotroph)

children.name: relationship to oxygen
children.description: Is this organism an aerobe, anaerobe? Please note that aerobic and anaerobic are valid descriptors for microbial environments

children.name: known pathogenicity
children.description: To what is the entity pathogenic, for instance plant, fungi, bacteria

children.name: encoded traits
children.description: Should include key traits like antibiotic resistance or xenobiotic degradation phenotypes for plasmids, converting genes for phage

children.name: observed biotic relationship
children.description: Is it free-living or in a host and if the latter what type of relationship is observed

children.name: chemical administration
children.description: list of chemical compounds administered to the host or site where sampling occurred, and when (e.g. antibiotics, N fertilizer, air filter); can include multiple compounds. For Chemical Entities of Biological Interest ontology (CHEBI) (v111), please see http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/CHEBI

children.name: perturbation
children.description: type of perturbation, e.g. chemical administration, physical disturbance, etc., coupled with time that perturbation occurred; can include multiple perturbation types

children.name: Part and developmental stage of organism
cell_type
children.description: cell type from which the sample was obtained

children.name: dev_stage
children.description: if the sample was obtained from an organism in a specific developmental stage, it is specified with this qualifier

children.name: germline
children.description: the sample described presented in the entry has not undergone somatic genomic rearrangement as part of an adaptive immune response; it is the unrearranged molecule that was inherited from the parental germline

children.name: tissue_lib
children.description: tissue library from which sample was obtained

children.name: tissue_type
children.description: tissue type from which the sample was obtained

children.name: isolation_source
children.description: describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived

children.name: lat_lon
children.description: geographical coordinates of the location where the specimen was collected

children.name: collected_by
children.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

children.name: collection date
children.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.

children.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
children.description: The location the sample was collected from with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).

children.name: geographic location (region and locality)
children.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

children.name: identified_by
children.description: name of the expert who identified the specimen taxonomically

children.name: environmental_sample
children.description: identifies sequences derived by direct molecular isolation from a bulk environmental DNA sample (by PCR with or without subsequent cloning of the product, DGGE, or other anonymous methods) with no reliable identification of the source organism

children.name: mating_type
children.description: mating type of the organism from which the sequence was obtained; mating type is used for prokaryotes, and for eukaryotes that undergo meiosis without sexually dimorphic gametes

children.name: sex
children.description: sex of the organism from which the sample was obtained

children.name: lab_host
children.description: scientific name of the laboratory host used to propagate the source organism from which the sample was obtained

children.name: host scientific name
children.description: Scientific name of the natural (as opposed to laboratory) host to the organism from which sample was obtained.

children.name: bio_material
children.description: Unique identifier that references the biological material from which the sample was obtained and that ideally exists in a curated collection (e.g. stock centres, seed banks, DNA banks). The ID should have the following structure: name of the institution (institution code) followed by the collection code (if available) and the voucher id (institution_code:collection_code:voucher_id). Please note institution codes and collection codes are taken from a controlled vocabulary maintained by the INSDC: https://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/taxonomy/biocollections/

children.name: culture_collection
children.description: Unique identifier that references the culture (e.g. live microbial and viral cultures and cell lines) from which the sample has been obtained and that have been deposited in curated culture collections. The ID needs to provide an institution code and the culture id, with optional collection code, in the following structure: (-institution_code:(collection_code):voucher_id. Please note institution codes (and optional collection codes) are taken from a controlled vocabulary maintained by the INSDC: https://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/taxonomy/biocollections/

children.name: specimen_voucher
children.description: Unique identifier that references the physical specimen that remains after the sequence has been obtained and that ideally exists in a curated collection. The ID should have the following structure: name of the institution (institution code) followed by the collection code (if available) and the voucher id (institution_code:collection_code:voucher_id). Please note institution codes and collection codes are taken from a controlled vocabulary maintained by the INSDC: https://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/taxonomy/biocollections/

children.name: cultivar
children.description: cultivar (cultivated variety) of plant from which sample was obtained

children.name: ecotype
children.description: a population within a given species displaying genetically based, phenotypic traits that reflect adaptation to a local habitat.

children.name: isolate
children.description: individual isolate from which the sample was obtained

children.name: sub_species
children.description: name of sub-species of organism from which sample was obtained

children.name: variety
children.description: variety (= varietas, a formal Linnaean rank) of organism from which sample was derived.

children.name: sub_strain
children.description: name or identifier of a genetically or otherwise modified strain from which sample was obtained, derived from a parental strain (which should be annotated in the strain field; sub_strain from which sample was obtained

children.name: cell_line
children.description: cell line from which the sample was obtained

children.name: serotype
children.description: serological variety of a species characterized by its antigenic properties

children.name: serovar
children.description: serological variety of a species (usually a prokaryote) characterized by its antigenic properties

children.name: strain
children.description: Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.
